Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: From the activities, it seems like each case goes through several stages: ApplicationReceived, DataValidation, PreliminaryScoring, ManualReview, and FinalDecision.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at the PreliminaryScore and ScoreAdjustment columns, I notice that some cases get a +10 adjustment from the Community group. For example, C001 and C004 both have the Highland Civic Darts Club listed under CommunityGroup and received a +10 adjustment.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: On the other hand, cases without a CommunityGroup, like C002, C003, and C005, don't get this adjustment. Wait, but C003 was rejected even though their preliminary score was 715, which is higher than C001's initial 710.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: That makes me think that being part of a community group gives an advantage, which might not be based on their actual creditworthiness.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Also, all the cases where LocalResident is TRUE, except for C003, got approved. C003 was FALSE and got rejected. So there's a pattern where local residents are more likely to be approved, perhaps because they can be part of a community group that gives a score boost.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The ScoreAdjustment seems to be the main point of bias. It's adding points based on community affiliation, which might not be a fair measure of creditworthiness. This could unfairly benefit those who are part of these groups while penalizing others who aren't, even if their financial situations are similar.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Reviewer #7 and Reviewer #2 handled cases with community adjustments and approved them. Reviewer #3 and #4 handled cases without adjustments, and their decisions were approved or rejected based on the score.

Name: Counterfactual Reasoning - PE
Text: If C003 had gotten the +10, their score would have been 725, which might have led to approval. So the adjustment is making a significant difference.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: If the engine is using these adjusted scores, then the bias is baked into the automated system. This could perpetuate unfair advantages for certain groups, leading to inequitable outcomes.

Name: Ethical or Moral Reasoning - PE
Text: If the system relies on these adjustments, it might not be assessing each applicant fairly. It's possible that the community adjustments are meant to encourage local participation, but they might be inadvertently creating barriers for others.
